en: The purpose of this type of drawing was the general understanding of the structure of human anatomy within a specific composition. Leonardo became the master of this practice by pursuing his scientific interest, studying real human corpses, particularly whilst he was in Milan in the late 1480s and 1490s. Not many artists in the following century continued this example, preferring to make studies from life. The abundance of surviving anatomical studies for arms, legs, fingers and feet by Barocci, demonstrates his obsessive attention to every detail of his figures. However it is curious to notice how, after having spent such a long time studying every single element of the composition, Barocci more than other painters, often altered his plan when setting paint to canvas. Although his figures are grounded in life study, he moved away from a descriptive naturalism in favour of a graceful idealism.

description: The purpose of this type of drawing was the general understanding of the structure of human anatomy within a specific composition. Leonardo became the master of this practice by pursuing his scientific interest, studying real human corpses, particularly whilst he was in Milan in the late 1480s and 1490s. Not many artists in the following century continued this example, preferring to make studies from life. The abundance of surviving anatomical studies for arms, legs, fingers and feet by Barocci, demonstrates his obsessive attention to every detail of his figures. However it is curious to notice how, after having spent such a long time studying every single element of the composition, Barocci more than other painters, often altered his plan when setting paint to canvas. Although his figures are grounded in life study, he moved away from a descriptive naturalism in favour of a graceful idealism.

en: R20: Federico Barocci, Study for Saint John's Right Arm and Hand with the Goldfinch, before 1575–6, black, red and white chalk on blue paper, (19.3 x 17.8 cm), (inv. KdZ 20518 (4244), Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Kupferstichkabinett) Barocci is a celebrated animal painter. After having studied the anatomy of Saint John the Baptist’s right arm in this rather damaged sheet, he focuses on the saint’s hand holding the animated goldfinch. He depicts the bird in detail and experiments with the pose of its head and its legs. The bird’s form and placement are a primary concern for him, but he is also exploring how to create the dynamism revealed in the saint’s arm holding the restless goldfinch, which is shown ready to retreat after the cat’s imminent pounce. © Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Kupferstichkabinett / Volker-H. Schneider (3598x3324px)

R35: Federico Barocci, Study for the Virgin's Right Arm and Hand, before 1575–6, black, red and white chalk, charcoal and white heightening on blue paper, (41 x 26.7 cm), (inv. 11635 F recto, Gabinetto dei Disegni e delle Stampe, Galleria degli Uffizi, Florence) This drawing may possibly be the last of the series dedicated to the key feature of the Virgin’s right hand. Barocci here explored both her hand and her arm. In the upper part of the drawing he first looked at a naked arm (on the left and in the centre) and then he drew it again clothed (on the right). In the bottom part of the sheet he seems to have defined the final position of the Virgin’s right thumb suppressing the view of her nail, as he does in the painting. The drapery study on the bottom right is probably for the white cloth in the basket to the right of the composition. © By courtesy of the Ministero per i Beni e le Attività Culturali (2796x4330px)

R40.1: Federico Barocci, Study for Saint John's Legs, before 1575–6, charcoal on blue paper, (24 x 18.3 cm), (inv. 1682 recto, Galleria Nazionale delle Marche, Urbino) This study made for the legs of Saint John the Baptist was probably done from life. It is hard to establish at what stage in the artist’s compositional process it was carried out. The child’s left foot is omitted in the painting due to the presence of the Virgin’s feet, whereas in the drawing Barocci explores the area underneath the child’s pelvis in full. He also places the foot on a solid surface, while in the painting Saint John seems to be seated with no weight on his feet. Photo © courtesy the Soprintendenza per i Beni Storici Artistici ed Etnoantropologici delle Marche, Urbino su concessione del Ministero per i Beni e le Attività Culturali (2340x1752px)

R40.2: Federico Barocci, Study for Saint John's Leg, before 1575–6, charcoal on blue paper, (24 x 18.3 cm), (inv. 1682 verso, Galleria Nazionale delle Marche, Urbino) This quick sketch could be a study for Saint John the Baptist’s right leg in ‘The Madonna of the Cat (‘La Madonna del Gatto’)’. Barocci initially used the sheet vertically, but then turned it clockwise and started another horizontal study of a leg. If we compare this study with the similar sketch on the verso of the Urbino drawing (R40.1) the leg depicted here is much more muscular. Photo © courtesy the Soprintendenza per i Beni Storici Artistici ed Etnoantropologici delle Marche, Urbino su concessione del Ministero per i Beni e le Attività Culturali (2537x1850px)

R33: Federico Barocci, Study for the Virgin's right hand, before 1575–6, black and red chalk on white paper, (12 x 28.5 cm), (inv. 11583 F recto, Gabinetto dei Disegni e delle Stampe, Galleria degli Uffizi, Florence) In this main study for the Virgin’s right hand, Barocci is still thinking of showing the three external fingers flexed inside the palm and providing a frontal view of her thumb. He will remain uncertain as to how to depict the hand until he reproduces it on canvas. Even at this stage, the painting’s underdrawing reveals that he explored several possibilities before choosing to depict a somewhat open hand. Visible on the right is a sketch for the upper part of the hand, while on the left the artist has turned the sheet round to study the fall of the drapery over the Virgin’s exposed breast once again. © By courtesy of the Ministero per i Beni e le Attività Culturali (2651x6351px)

R34: Federico Barocci, Study for the Virgin's Right Hand and for the Right Arm of Saint John, before 1575–6, black and red chalk on white paper, (12.7 x 17.1 cm), (inv. 11593 F recto, Gabinetto dei Disegni e delle Stampe degli Uffizi, Florence) Barocci spent a long time considering the feature of the Virgin’s pointing hand. Here he has masterly studied it in red chalk. In addition, he also uses this sheet to study Saint John the Baptist’s arm with the squiggle representing the goldfinch in his hand. Below right, Barocci with very thin lines of red chalk sketched the Virgin’s mantle above her naked breast. This section concerned him as he had to transform his study of a male model into a female figure in the painting. As a result, it has been suggested that the green mantle was developed in order to help him obtain the correct proportions. © Photo Scala, Florence - courtesy of the Ministero per i Beni e le Attività Culturali (2643x3528px)

R43.2: Federico Barocci, Study of thr Virgin's Right Hand, Pointing, before 1577, red chalk, with pen and ink additions on white paper, (30 x 23.8 cm), (inv. 1994-5-14-55 verso, The British Museum, London) At least four studies for the Virgin’s right hand survive today. This one, on the verso of the British Museum’s finished compositional drawing for ‘The Madonna of the Cat (‘La Madonna del Gatto’)’ (R43.1), was discovered in 1992 when the sheet was removed from its old backing. While Barocci had quite clearly decided on the pointing of the index finger, he is evidently struggling with the positioning of the other fingers. He draws them folded inside the palm here, but later decides to stretch the fingers out in the final composition. Technical examinations of the painting confirm the presence of several pentimenti in this part of the canvas. © The British Museum, London (2936x2327px)

NG29: Federico Barocci, The Madonna of the Cat ('La Madonna del Gatto'), probably about 1575, Oil on canvas, (112.7 x 92.7 cm) The young John the Baptist holds a goldfinch, a bird frequently kept as a pet but also a traditional symbol of Christ's Passion; the Baptist is teasing the cat shown in the left foreground by holding the bird above his head. The Virgin is suckling the Child and Saint Joseph looks on from the right.
NG 29 may be the picture painted, according to Bellori (1672), for Count Antonio Brancaleoni, who lived near Perugia. The design was engraved in reverse in 1577 by Cornelius Cort and the painting probably dates from about 1575. Numerous drawings made in preparation for NG 29 are known; a highly finished drawing made by Barocci in preparation for the engraving and formerly in the National Gallery is now in the British Museum.
The window and the bench in the background seem to be based on windows in the Palazzo Ducale, Urbino. There are several copies and workshop versions of the picture.
Cesarei collection, Perugia, by 1784; acquired in Italy by Buchanan, about 1805; collection of Revd Holwell Carr, 1807; by whom bequeathed, 1831.
Gould 1975, pp. 11-12
Emiliani 1985, I, pp. 93-103 Bequeathed by Revd Holwell Carr, 1831 (6000x4929px)
